Fig. 1 (a) The conversion of BA (0.1 g of catalyst, 50 mmol of anisole, 5 mmol of BA and T = 124 °C), (b) 13C NMR of 2-13C-acetone loaded on ZW and ZW-CTAB. Fig. 1 Fig. 2 HRTEM images of (a) ZW-CTAB and (b) ZW. Red circles indicated the WO3 clusters with diameters of 0.8–1.0 nm. (For interpretation of the references to colour in this figure legend, the reader is referred to the web version of this article.) Fig. 2 Fig. 3 (a) The conversion of BA (1 h) in the F–C reaction (0.1 g of catalyst, 50 mmol of anisole, 5 mmol of BA and T = 124 °C) and (b) Pyridine adsorbed FTIR spectra for ZW samples synthesized with different surfactants. Fig. 3 Table 1 Physical properties of ZW-S. Table 1 Sample SBET (m2/g) W density a (atom/nm2) BA conversion per surface area b Selectivity % c ZW 73.5 6.10 0.076 80.72 ZW-CTAB 90.1 5.08 0.714 87.82 ZW-OA 105.3 4.34 0.443 83.29 ZW-EDA 62.4 7.32 0.351 85.25 ZW-F127 95.8 4.77 0.003 99.9 ZW-SDS 39.4 11.60 0.002 99.9 a Based on over all W content in catalyst, W density = W mole·NA/surface area. b Catalytic reaction: 0.1 g of catalyst, 50 mmol of anisole, 5 mmol of BA, T = 124 °C, t = 1 h. c S % = (ortho-benzylanisole + para-benzylanisole)/(ortho-benzylanisole + para-benzylanisole + dibenzylether) ∗ 100%. Short communication Regulation of acidic properties of WO3-ZrO2 for Friedel–Crafts reaction with surfactant Sha Li a b Chuanhong Jin c Ningdong Feng d Feng Deng d Liping Xiao a ⁎ Jie Fan a ⁎ a Key Lab of Applied Chemistry of Zhejiang Province, Department of Chemistry, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province 310027, China Key Lab of Applied Chemistry of Zhejiang Province Department of Chemistry Zhejiang University Hangzhou Zhejiang Province 310027 China b Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Utilization of Forestry Biomass, Zhejiang A & F University, Lin'an, Zhejiang Province 311300, China Zhejiang Provincial Key Laboratory of Chemical Utilization of Forestry Biomass Zhejiang A & F University Lin'an Zhejiang Province 311300 China c State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials, Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Applications for Batteries of Zhejiang Province, Department of Materials Science and Engineering, Zhejiang University, Hangzhou, Zhejiang Province 310027,China State Key Laboratory of Silicon Materials Key Laboratory of Advanced Materials and Applications for Batteries of Zhejiang Province Department of Materials Science and Engineering Zhejiang University Hangzhou Zhejiang Province 310027 China d Wuhan Center for Magnetic Resonance, State Key Laboratory of Magnetic Resonance and Atomic and Molecular Physics, Wuhan Institute of Physics and Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Wuhan, Hubei Province 430071, China Wuhan Center for Magnetic Resonance State Key Laboratory of Magnetic Resonance and Atomic and Molecular Physics Wuhan Institute of Physics and Mathematics Chinese Academy of Sciences Wuhan Hubei Province 430071 China ⁎ Corresponding authors. WO3-ZrO2 mixed metal oxides were synthesized by a well-controlled sol-gel process using Zr(BuO)4 and WCl6 as the inorganic precursors in the presence of organic surfactants, followed by low-temperature calcination (550 °C). The results showed that the sub-nanometer WOx clusters acted as the strong Brønsted acid sites. And the N-type surfactants played a crucial role for the generation of acidic WOx clusters at low calcination temperature. Graphical abstract Unlabelled Image Keywords WO3-ZrO2 Acid catalysis Surfactants Low-temperature calcination 1 Introduction The strong acid catalysts, such as WO3-ZrO2 materials, have attracted much attention because of their ability to catalyze a range of reactions such as cracking, alkylation and isomerization. Up to now, several surface species, such as poly-tungstate [1], well-ordered WO3 nanocrystal and sub-nanometer distorted WOx clusters have been proposed to be the active sites [2,3]. Very recently, Zhou et al. identified that the sub-nanometer (0.8–1.0 nm) Zr-WOx clusters are the most active catalytic species by aberration-corrected high-angle annular dark-field (HAADF) imaging technique [4]. Many factors, such as the ZrO2 phase [5], the loading amount of tungsten [6], and the calcination temperature [7] would affect the acidity of WO3-ZrO2. All these factors were examined as a function of WOx surface density [8]. In order to improve the catalytic activity of WO3-ZrO2, some metal promoters, such as Mn, Pt and Fe can be added to the supports and these materials present good activity in n-hexane isomerization. In addition, the low surface area of WO3-ZrO2 is disadvantageous in catalytic reactions and surfactants are always used to address this issue. Hernandez et al. reported that the surfactant incorporation during synthesis process led to WO3-ZrO2 solids with higher surface area which favored the dispersion and accessibility of the tungsten species and allowed facile transport of reactants and products [9]. They revealed that the role of the surfactant was to separate the mixed oxide particles and avoid sintering and forming small particles that would increase the surface area and modify the pore size distribution [10]. These resulted catalysts exhibited high isomerization activity advantageously [11]. Regardless of many extensive works on the structure characterization of these solids and their relationship to the catalytic activity, little attention has been focused on an effective way for regulating the acidity of WO3-ZrO2 materials. A major objective of this work is to investigate the role of surfactants on the structures and the acidity of WO3-ZrO2 at low calcination temperature. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalysts preparation WO3-ZrO2 mixed oxides with different surfactants (ZW-S, S indicates the surfactant, CTAB: Hexadecyl Trimethyl Ammonium Bromide, OA: oleyl amine, EDA: ethylenediamine, SDS: sodium dodecyl sulfonate, F127: Pluronic® F-127) were synthesized according to our previously reported AcHE method [12] by using Zr(BuO)4 and WCl6 as the inorganic precursors. The as-synthesized samples were subsequently calcined at 550 °C for 5 h (ramp rate 2 °C/min) in air to obtain final products. Some properties of ZW-S are shown in Table 1 . 2.2 Characterization methods The X-ray diffraction (XRD) patterns were recorded on a Bruker D8 diffract meter with Cu KR radiation. Nitrogen adsorption-desorption analysis was carried out at 77 K on a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 adsorption analyzer. Before the adsorption analysis, samples were out gassed under a vacuum at 300 °C in the port of the adsorption analyzer. Raman spectroscopy with a visible (514.532 nm) laser excitation on JobinYvon-Lab. HR800 Raman spectrometer equipped with a co focal microscope (LMPlanFI 50*/0.50, JAPAN) and a cooled CCD detector (−70 °C) with a spectral resolution of 1 cm−1. Infrared measurements (IR) were performed on a TENSOR 27 Spectrometer. Pyridine was introduced to the IR cell at 150 °C, pyridine adsorption IR spectra of samples were measured at ambient temperature after desorption at 300 °C. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy analysis (XPS): XPS experiments were carried out on an RBD upgraded PHI-5000C ESCA system (Perkin Elmer) with Mg Kα radiation (hν = 1253.6 eV) or Al Kα radiation (hν = 1486.6 eV). Binding energies were calibrated by using the contained carbon (C1s = 284.6 eV). Transmission electron microscopy (TEM): The TEM images were taken using a JEOL 2010 electron microscope operating at 200 kV. High angle angular dark-field (HAADF) was performed with an aberration-corrected Titan ChemiSTEM equipped with a probe corrector (CEOS). This microscope was operated at 200 kV with an optimum attainable resolution of 0.078 nm. Solid Nuclear Magnetic Resonance (NMR) data was collected on a Varian Infinity Plus-300 spectrometer at 7.05 T, equipped with a triple-resonance 4.0 mm probe, with resonance frequencies of 75.39 MHz for 13C. Typically, a π/2 pulse length of 4.1 μs was used for 13C resonance. For the 1H → 13C CP MAS spectra, the Hartmann-Hahn condition was optimized using hexamethylbenzene (HMB) with a contact time of 4.0 ms and a recycle delay of 2.0 s. 2.3 Acid-catalyzed reaction The acid catalytic activity of WO3-ZrO2 was performed in the Friedel-Crafts (F–C) reaction of anisole and benzyl alcohol. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properites XRD was used to characterize the crystalline structure. Fig. S1 showed that there existed tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) and monoclinic zirconia (m-ZrO2) in both ZW and ZW-CTAB materials. No peaks corresponding to bulk crystallized tungsten oxide (WO3) were found for both samples, suggesting that the addition of CTAB do not affect the phase of the resulted catalysts. This can be further confirmed by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S1). Comparing to ZW, the up-shift from 949 to 961 cm−1 for ZW-CTAB was associated with the transition from monomeric to polymeric tungsten species [13]. XRD was used to characterize the crystalline structure. Fig. S1 showed that there existed tetragonal ZrO2 (t-ZrO2) and monoclinic zirconia (m-ZrO2) in both ZW and ZW-CTAB materials. No peaks corresponding to bulk crystallized tungsten oxide (WO3) were found for both samples, suggesting that the addition of CTAB do not affect the phase of the resulted catalysts. This can be further confirmed by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S1). Comparing to ZW, the up-shift from 949 to 961 cm−1 for ZW-CTAB was associated with the transition from monomeric to polymeric tungsten species [13]. 3.2 Catalytic activity Friedel-Crafts reactions of anisole and benzyl alcohol are well known to be catalyzed by strong or moderate strong Brønsted acid sites [14]. Fig. 1a shows the catalytic results for ZW-CTAB and ZW samples on the F–C reaction of anisole and BA. After 1 h, the conversion of BA for ZW-CTAB is 64.3%, which is 10 times higher than that of the surfactant free sample ZW (5.6%). The enhanced catalytic activity in F–C reaction for ZW-CTAB could be attributed to its strong Brønsted acid sites. However, it should be noted that the only difference between these two samples is adding CTAB or not during the synthesis, suggesting that the surfactant CTAB is very important for the generation of active acid sites. 3.3 Acidic properties The acid properties of the catalysts were evaluated by 13C CP/MAS NMR of 2-13C-acetone. The signal at 226 ppm was ascribed to the unreacted 2-13C-acetone molecules which are adsorbed on the strong Brønsted acid sites [15]. Besides, the concentration of strong Brønsted acid sites for ZW-CTAB is as 5 times as high as that of ZW based on the calculation of the peak area at 226 ppm. The acid properties are further verified by pyridine adsorption IR spectra (Fig. S2). These results confirmed that ZW-CTAB has much more strong acid sites than that of ZW, suggesting that the surfactant CTAB plays a very crucial role for generating acid sites. The acid properties of the catalysts were evaluated by 13C CP/MAS NMR of 2-13C-acetone. The signal at 226 ppm was ascribed to the unreacted 2-13C-acetone molecules which are adsorbed on the strong Brønsted acid sites [15]. Besides, the concentration of strong Brønsted acid sites for ZW-CTAB is as 5 times as high as that of ZW based on the calculation of the peak area at 226 ppm. The acid properties are further verified by pyridine adsorption IR spectra (Fig. S2). These results confirmed that ZW-CTAB has much more strong acid sites than that of ZW, suggesting that the surfactant CTAB plays a very crucial role for generating acid sites. 3.4 The structures of Zr-WOx It is well known that sub-nanometer Zr-WOx clusters are important factors in terms of Brønsted acidity. The formation of Zr-WOx clusters could be confirmed using HRTEM and HAADF imaging technique (Fig.2 and Fig. S3). Some dark speckles are found at the boundaries and the surfaces of the aggregated ZrO2 nanoparticles in ZW-CTAB (Fig. 2a), implying the formation of some amorphous interfacial films or clusters on the surface. Instead of dark speckles, ZW displays only typical porous frameworks (Fig. 2b). HAADF images of ZW-CTAB and ZW are shown in Fig. S3. No sub-nanometer WOx clusters or discrete WO3 nanocrystals can be seen in ZW. On the contrary, numerous WOx clusters (red circles) with a size of 0.8–1 nm emerge in ZW-CTAB, indicating that the surfactant CTAB is very crucial for the formation of subnanometer WOx clusters, which are the most active acidic species and account for the enhanced catalytic activity [4]. It is well known that sub-nanometer Zr-WOx clusters are important factors in terms of Brønsted acidity. The formation of Zr-WOx clusters could be confirmed using HRTEM and HAADF imaging technique (Fig.2 and Fig. S3). Some dark speckles are found at the boundaries and the surfaces of the aggregated ZrO2 nanoparticles in ZW-CTAB (Fig. 2a), implying the formation of some amorphous interfacial films or clusters on the surface. Instead of dark speckles, ZW displays only typical porous frameworks (Fig. 2b). HAADF images of ZW-CTAB and ZW are shown in Fig. S3. No sub-nanometer WOx clusters or discrete WO3 nanocrystals can be seen in ZW. On the contrary, numerous WOx clusters (red circles) with a size of 0.8–1 nm emerge in ZW-CTAB, indicating that the surfactant CTAB is very crucial for the formation of subnanometer WOx clusters, which are the most active acidic species and account for the enhanced catalytic activity [4]. The W oxidation states or the local symmetry may also have significant influence on the acidic properties and the subsequent catalytic activity [16]. XPS indicated that all W species in both samples were in 6+ oxidation state (WO3) (Fig. S4) [6]. That means the surfactant CTAB does not affect the W oxidation state. The surface W/Zr ratio of both catalysts is similar (0.30 for ZW and 0.33 for ZW-CTAB) detected by XPS，suggesting that surface W/Zr ratio is not an important factor for the acidity. According to XRD analyses, the tetragonal phase for ZW and ZW-CTAB is 0.67 and 0.64 respectively, which means ZrO2 phase would not affect the acidity of WO3-ZrO2. The stability of ZW-CTAB sample was investigated. The conversion of BA is from 64.3% to 61.7%, the selectivity is from 87.8% to 85.5%, showed little loss in activity after four recycles, suggesting catalyst little deactivation (Fig. S5). The W oxidation states or the local symmetry may also have significant influence on the acidic properties and the subsequent catalytic activity [16]. XPS indicated that all W species in both samples were in 6+ oxidation state (WO3) (Fig. S4) [6]. That means the surfactant CTAB does not affect the W oxidation state. The surface W/Zr ratio of both catalysts is similar (0.30 for ZW and 0.33 for ZW-CTAB) detected by XPS，suggesting that surface W/Zr ratio is not an important factor for the acidity. According to XRD analyses, the tetragonal phase for ZW and ZW-CTAB is 0.67 and 0.64 respectively, which means ZrO2 phase would not affect the acidity of WO3-ZrO2. The stability of ZW-CTAB sample was investigated. The conversion of BA is from 64.3% to 61.7%, the selectivity is from 87.8% to 85.5%, showed little loss in activity after four recycles, suggesting catalyst little deactivation (Fig. S5). 3.5 The effect of surfactants To further confirm the role of the surfactant, a series of ZW-S materials were synthesized with different surfactants. The catalytic activities of ZW-S are shown in Fig. 3(a). ZW-S materials synthesized with nitrogen atoms included surfactants (denoted as N-type), such as ethylenediamine (ZW-EDA), oleyl amine (ZW-OA) and Hexadecyl Trimethyl Ammonium Bromide (ZW-CTAB), exhibit enhanced acid catalytic activities (the conversion of BA >22%), while those synthesized with surfactants without N atoms (non-N-type), such as anionic sodium dodecyl sulfonate (ZW-SDS) and nonionic surfactants F127 (ZW-F127), show very low catalytic activity (the conversion of BA <8%). Fig. 3 (b) shows the pyridine adsorption IR spectra for ZW-S materials. The spectra of N-type surfactant samples, such as ZW-CTAB, ZW-EDA and ZW-OA, show Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites. While, no obvious peak is detected for ZW-SDS and ZW-F127, suggesting that these samples synthesized with non-N-type surfactants showed neither Lewis acid sites nor Brønsted acid sites. These facts confirm that the N-type surfactants are very important for generating both of Lewis and Brønsted acid sites in WO3-ZrO2 materials. The amorphous nature of W species in ZW-S is confirmed by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S6). Comparing to ZW-F127 and ZW-SDS, the up-shift from 942 cm−1 (950 cm−1 in ZW-F127) to about 970 cm−1 for ZW-EDA (973 cm−1) and ZW-CTAB (961 cm−1) was associated with the transition from monomeric to polymeric tungsten species [13,17]. The signals of ZW-OA in Raman spectra of are weak due to strong fluorescence. XPS indicates that the all W species in all samples were in 6+ oxidation state, suggests the surfactant does not affect the W oxidation state (Fig. S7). The amorphous nature of W species in ZW-S is confirmed by Raman spectroscopy (Fig. S6). Comparing to ZW-F127 and ZW-SDS, the up-shift from 942 cm−1 (950 cm−1 in ZW-F127) to about 970 cm−1 for ZW-EDA (973 cm−1) and ZW-CTAB (961 cm−1) was associated with the transition from monomeric to polymeric tungsten species [13,17]. The signals of ZW-OA in Raman spectra of are weak due to strong fluorescence. XPS indicates that the all W species in all samples were in 6+ oxidation state, suggests the surfactant does not affect the W oxidation state (Fig. S7). 3.6 Discussion It was found that the incorporation of CTAB did not change the structure of the resulted ZW-CTAB catalyst. Although the surface area of ZW-CTAB is improved by 20%, the W atom density of ZW-CTAB and ZW lies in the same range (5–8 W atoms/nm2), suggesting that ZW-CTAB and ZW should have similar catalytic activity according to previous reports [18]. Actually, ZW-CTAB does exhibit 10 times higher catalytic activity than that of ZW in F–C reaction. There is a noticeable change of the surface area for the samples synthesized with different surfactants (Table 1). Their W density of ZW-S varies from 4.3 to 11.6 atom/nm2 and these samples display very different catalytic activity. For example, ZW-F127 and ZW-OA have the same “nominal” W density (4.34 and 4.77 atom/nm2) which falls into poly-tungstate W species. However, the former is totally inactive (the conversion of BA is 0.26%) for F–C reaction，but the later exhibits significant activity (the conversion of BA is 46.6%), suggesting that the W density is not the key factor for the catalytic activity. This isn't consistent with previous reports, which indicated that the highest catalytic activity was usually associated with the intermediate W surface densities (5–8 W atoms/nm2) [19] [20]. The obvious difference in catalytic activity between ZW-CTAB and ZW only depends on if there exist 0.8–1.0 nm Zr-WOx clusters or not, implying that the Zr-WOx clusters are the active sites for Friedel-Crafts reaction. Generally, the temperature for formation of WOx cluster is above 650 °C [21,22]. Our results here demonstrated that WOx clusters could be formed at the low calcination temperature of 550 °C by using N-type surfactants during the synthesis process. That means the role of surfactants is very crucial for the formation of Zr-WOx clusters at a low calcination temperature. Recently, some reports have pointed out that the addition of surfactants can regulate the electrostatic interaction between the surface charges and the adsorbed layers [23,24]. The acid-base chemistry of the particle surface and the surfactants were found to play critical roles in determining the sign and magnitude of the particle charge. This is consistent with the acid-base charging mechanism initially proposed by Fowkes and coworkers [25]. The Charge-matching at the organic-inorganic interface is critical factor for the catalyst's activity [26,27]. Based on the above-mentioned analyses, it is found that the surfactants play a very crucial role for the formation of sub-nanometer Zr-WOx clusters (0.8–1.0 nm) at low calcination temperature (at 550 °C). And a model for the formation of W–Zr subnanometer clusters was proposed. During the synthesis process, the inorganic W species, which are negatively charged at the synthesis pH (pH = 2.9 > PI = 2.0), preferentially interact with the positively charged alkyl ammonium head-groups of the surfactants. The strong covalent bonds between the metal-oxide species and the N-type surfactant head-groups [25,28], for example, between WOX − and R-NH2 + group, may lead to generate the strong acid sites owing to their special charge interaction. And this strong charge interaction is also beneficial surface segregation of the W atoms into WO3 clusters. However, when there is no special charge interaction between the inorganic W species and the surfactants, for example, when using those non-N-type surfactants, surface mono-tungstate species would exist in WO3-ZrO2 related materials. 4 Conclusions In summary, WO3-ZrO2 materials with both strong Brønsted acid sites and Lewis acid sites were successfully synthesized by using N-type surfactants at low calcination temperature (550 °C). The resulted materials exhibit excellent catalytic activity in the F–C reaction of anisole and benzyl alcohol. It was found that the special charge interactions between the surfactants (N atom) and the W–Zr oxide species (W atom) would induce the formation of 0.8–1 nm sub-nanometer WOx clusters which act as the strong acid sites. More importantly, the formation of sub-nanometer WOx clusters can be well controlled by the type of the surfactants, which is of great importance for the design of the solid acids with strong acid sites. coredata.dc:description: WO3-ZrO2 mixed metal oxides were synthesized by a well-controlled sol-gel process using Zr(BuO)4 and WCl6 as the inorganic precursors in the presence of organic surfactants, followed by low-temperature calcination (550 °C). The results showed that the sub-nanometer WOx clusters acted as the strong Brønsted acid sites. And the N-type surfactants played a crucial role for the generation of acidic WOx clusters at low calcination temperature.
coredata.dc:title: Regulation of acidic properties of WO3-ZrO2 for Friedel–Crafts reaction with surfactant
